medical: PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSES: 1. Benign prostatic hypertrophy. 2. Urinary retention. POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSES: 1. Benign prostatic hypertrophy. 2. Urinary retention. PROCEDURE PERFORMED: 1. Cystourethroscopy. 2. Transurethral resection of prostate (TURP). ANESTHESIA: Spinal. DRAIN: A #24 French three-way Foley catheter. SPECIMENS: Prostatic resection chips. ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS: 150 cc. DISPOSITION: The patient was transferred to the PACU in stable condition. INDICATIONS AND FINDINGS: This is an 84-year-old male with history of BPH and subsequent urinary retention with failure of trial of void, scheduled for elective TURP procedure. FINDINGS: At the time of surgery, cystourethroscopy revealed trilobar enlargement of the prostate with prostatic varices of the median lobe. Cystoscopy showed a few cellules of the bladder with no obvious bladder tumors noted. DESCRIPTION OF PROCEDURE: After informed consent was obtained, the patient was moved to operating room and spinal anesthesia was induced by the Department of Anesthesia. The patient was prepped and draped in the normal sterile fashion and a #21 French cystoscope inserted into urethra and into the bladder. Cystoscopy performed with the above findings. Cystoscope was removed. A #27 French resectoscope with a #26 cutting loop was inserted into the bladder. Verumontanum was identified as a landmark and systematic transurethral resection of the prostate tissue was undertaken in an circumferential fashion with good resection of tissue completed. ________ irrigator was used to evacuate the bladder of prostatic chips. Resectoscope was then inserted and any residual chips were removed in piecemeal fashion with a resectoscope loop. Any obvious bleeding from the prostatic fossa was controlled with electrocautery. Resectoscope was removed. A #24 French three-way Foley catheter inserted into the urethra and into the bladder. Bladder was irrigated and connected to three-way irrigation. The patient was cleaned and sent to recovery in stable condition to be admitted overnight for continuous bladder irrigation and postop monitoring.
layman:
**Pre‑operative diagnosis:**  
1. Enlarged prostate (benign prostatic hypertrophy).  
2. Urinary retention.

**Post‑operative diagnosis:**  
1. Enlarged prostate.  
2. Urinary retention.

**Procedure performed:**  
1. Cystourethroscopy (looking inside the bladder and urethra).  
2. Transurethral resection of the prostate (TURP).

**Anesthesia:** Spinal.

**Drain:** A #24 French three‑way Foley catheter.

**Specimens:** Pieces of removed prostate tissue.

**Estimated blood loss:** 150 cc.

**Disposition:** The patient was sent to the post‑anesthesia care unit (PACU) in stable condition.

---

### Indications and findings

An 84‑year‑old man with a history of enlarged prostate and urinary retention that did not improve after a trial of voiding was scheduled for an elective TURP.  
During surgery, cystourethroscopy showed a three‑lobe enlargement of the prostate with varices (enlarged veins) in the middle lobe. A few small cells were seen in the bladder, but no obvious bladder tumors were found.

### Description of procedure

After the patient gave informed consent, he was taken to the operating room and spinal anesthesia was started. The area was cleaned and covered with sterile drapes. A #21 French cystoscope was inserted through the urethra into the bladder to confirm the findings. The cystoscope was then removed.

A #27 French resectoscope with a #26 cutting loop was inserted. The verumontanum (a normal landmark) was identified, and the prostate tissue was removed in a circular pattern. The bladder was irrigated to remove the prostate chips. Any remaining chips were removed piece by piece with the resectoscope loop. Any bleeding from the prostate area was controlled with electrocautery. The resectoscope was removed.

A #24 French three‑way Foley catheter was inserted into the urethra and bladder. The bladder was irrigated and connected to a three‑way irrigation system. The patient was cleaned and sent to recovery in stable condition. He will stay overnight for continuous bladder irrigation and postoperative monitoring.
